title: Is there any simple way to identify Dry Stars and Polar Stars? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve never heard the term Dry Star. I can only imagine it has something to do with the amount of hydrogen present but that’s only a guess. A google search didn’t return any relevant results. If you can provide more info, that would help. Polar stars are those that appear to be near the northern or south celestial pole. The most noteworthy is Polaris, which appears to be less than a degree from the north celestial pole, at least for now. Due to the wobble in the earth’s axis, it changes over time. You can consider other stars that are in that general region of the sky to be polar stars. Similarly in the southern hemisphere, the closest naked-eye-visible star to the south celestial pole is sigma octans, which is a bit further from the pole than is Polaris, but, again, there’s other stars in that part of the sky that could be considered polar stars, though not “the” pole star.
